Although that's true for any cryptoasset
When have I questioned your or anyone's integrity at ripple? This is a straight forward insult. I'm leaving this conversation now. It's been fun twitter.

Strong opinions weakly held. I remain unconvinced of wrong doing, on any side here. Ripple remains compelling, with talented technical staff and an interesting value proposition. Me questioning the gap between perception and reality isn't wrong. What am I missing?

Do you think it's helpful to the long term credibility of an organization to use a crypto trader term like "FUD" or that there is a chrous of boos and hissing from a mob of Twitter accounts it someone is vaguely critical of any part of the ripple story or narrative?

I believe a lot of people are testing ripple products. I also believe a lot of journos are getting confused about what's xrp and what isn't and that's a blurred line that suits people who are long xrp. Do you believe it doesn't suit people who hold xrp?

Yes. And I'll admit it's ambiguous and varies. The original conversation was - I doubt xrp is used as much as some PR would suggest. The ripple community seems angry about that statement. I also doubt the legal status of xrp as a bearer asset. Recognise that it's a grey area

I think you just summed up why I find the concept challenging from a financial services standpoint. That appears exactly like what they've done. Which makes it more of an IOU propped up by the believers. It looks to me like ripple* lent themselves a new asset they made up
Agreed. The question is the mechanism and therefore the definition of how it came into being. You can say that no person issued a freshly mined Bitcoin. Harder to say for xrp.

That would work if like bitcoin there were no human that instructed the pre mine of those tokens. Bitcoin has a clear network algorithm we can all see and understand how the Bitcoin comes into being. It's more akin to gold The ripple ledger isn't the same
Which works IF you believe ripple is a complaint issuer of an asset. Which I think is a challenging position to take Therefore it's not functioning as bearer
Is that clear in the shit loads of pr companies contacting me saying ripple did a thing? Definitely not!! I'm happy to send you some of these press releases.

Ripple as a network issues IOUs in return for fiat - much like PayPal would. Xrp is in effect issued by the dominant controller of the ripple network. Ripple labs inc. It's acting like a central bank and that raises real governance questions - that's not a red herring at all

I've said before and I say again. For corporates wanting to avoid the banking system ripple is interesting. The concept of a natively digital asset is super interesting. But the creation and ownership structure of xrp isn't as simple as gold.

That works great if I hold a ton of xrp. Which requires the asset becoming much more legitimate. But it's setup and ripple labs dominance scares off mainstream banks. Large corporations I can see it for. But I don't see a direct parallel with gold if it were gifted by founders
No it is an IOU. That's exactly what it is. Unless ripple are a central bank. I exchange fiat for xrp and the only entity that settles xrp is ripple.

"nobody" was not used as an absolute term. For the 100+ companies working with ripple you can cite 6 using xrp in pilot mode. Yet the headlines often mix xrp and other services from ripple with corrections coming from the likes of use exchange

Bearer assets have an issuer. Physical notes are a bearer instruments, the issuer is a central bank. Ripple is in effect playing the role of an asset issuer. Bearer assets are subject to settlement and credit risks, which *are* counterparty risks.
